channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Kanye West, Gap's Co-branded Jacket Sells Out In Hours
item.description: + Cool marketing: To promote the release, the jacket's being projected old-school-cinema-style throughout NYC, LA, and Kanye's own Chi City.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 9
item.description: (Jackie Bryant) Read: If you give a lobster enough THC, will it notice that it is boiling to death?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Spotify, Amazon, and More Sites Experience Outages
item.description: Bottom line: One hour offline may not sound like a lot, but it can translate to millions of dollars in advertising revenue and e-commerce losses for affected sites.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: ProPublica Estimates that Richest 25 Individuals Pay 3.4% Tax Rate
item.description: ProPublica estimates that America's richest 25 people paid a cumulative $13.6 billion in income taxes between 2014 and 2018, a span during which their collective wealth increased $400+ billion, for a "true tax rate" that was just 3.4%. For every $100 gained, Bezos paid just $1.09 while the typical US household paid $160. Okay, we knew that before...
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: FBI, International Authorities Arrest Hundreds In Encrypted Messaging App Sting
item.description: The FBI also helped spread Anom by distributing devices to 300+ gangs across 100 countries through middlemen.  As the FBI took down other encrypted communication services, more criminals started to DM using Anom's platform. For almost three years, criminals used a network of encrypted devices to share the dirty details of their smuggling and money laundering operations. The engineer was working on a new service, Anom, that stripped mobile phones of their normal functions and disguised a secure messaging app to look like a calculator.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Spotify, Amazon, and More Sites Experience Outages
item.description: Bottom line: One hour offline may not sound like a lot, but it can translate to millions of dollars in advertising revenue and e-commerce losses for affected sites.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Kanye West, Gap's Co-branded Jacket Sells Out In Hours
item.description: Just in time for Kanye West's 44th birthday and summer, Gap and Yeezy unveiled the first product of their partnership yesterday: the jacket you see above.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.description: (Jackie Bryant) Read: If you give a lobster enough THC, will it notice that it is boiling to death?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: FBI, International Authorities Arrest Hundreds In Encrypted Messaging App Sting
item.description: The FBI also helped spread Anom by distributing devices to 300+ gangs across 100 countries through middlemen.  As the FBI took down other encrypted communication services, more criminals joined Anom's platform to DM. For almost three years, criminals used a network of encrypted devices to share the dirty details of their smuggling and money laundering operations. Still, Anom represented just a fraction of criminal communications.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: ProPublica Estimates that Richest 25 Individuals Pay 3.4% Tax Rate
item.description: ProPublica estimates that America's richest 25 people paid a cumulative $13.6 billion in income taxes between 2014 and 2018, a span during which their collective wealth increased $400+ billion, for a "true tax rate" that was just 3.4%. For every $100 gained, Bezos paid just $1.09 while the typical US household paid $160. Okay, we knew that before...
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Jeff Bezos to Travel to Space on Blue Origin's First Passenger-Carrying Mission
item.description: Jeff Bezos is launching himself into space. So if you've been looking to get some Bezos facetime to pitch your startup idea, you can bid for New Shepard's final seat through Saturday.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 8
item.description: (Noahpinion)  Read: Is our society turning into a zero-sum competition for survival?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: CO2 In Air Hit Highest Level in Modern History
item.description: A brief commuting break can’t offset the CO2 that sticks around in the atmosphere for up to 1,000 years.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: FDA Approves First Alzheimer's Drug to Treat Underlying Cause
item.description: Yesterday, the FDA approved Biogen's aducanumab, the first drug to treat the underlying cause of Alzheimer's (sticky brain plaques) and potentially slow the disease's progression in early stage patients. There's certainly money to be made: Biogen says the treatment, which will be sold under the name “Aduhelm,” will cost $56,000 a year.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Apple Unveils New Privacy and Work Features at WWDC
item.description: If Apple loses, the company may have to rewrite the rules of its money-printing App Store. Yesterday, Apple defended itself and said the App Store has paid over $230 billion to developers since opening in 2008. Apple kicked off its annual WWDC conference for developers with a keynote address showing off its new software features. Apple users will be able to block tracking by email senders, a change that could mean big disruptions for businesses that depend on email marketing. And trusted contacts to get you back into iCloud after you forget your new password. Fancier maps.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.description: If Apple loses, the company may have to rewrite the rules of its money-printing App Store. Yesterday, Apple defended itself and said the App Store has paid over $230 billion to developers since opening in 2008. Apple kicked off its annual WWDC conference for developers with a keynote address showing off its new software features. Apple users will be able to block tracking by email senders, a change that could mean big disruptions for businesses that depend on email marketing. And trusted contacts to get you back into iCloud after you forget your new password. Fancier maps.

item.title: Brew Mini: Summer Slushie
item.author: Mary Tobler

item.title: The Week Ahead: June 7
item.description: Everything else: Going to genuinely write “Happy Friday” in every correspondence on Friday, because on that day…Soccer’s European Championship startsThe Pulitzer Prize winners are announcedIn the Heights comes to theaters
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 7
item.description: Read: Profiles of NBA stars Russell Westbrook and Kevin Durant from the NYT Magazine. On ABC yesterday, Facebook executive Nick Clegg defended the company’s decision to ban former President Trump’s account for at least two years.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Booster Shot FAQ
item.description: Likely not, though studies are progressing to make sure vaccine mashups are safe. However, Dr. Peter Marks of the FDA told CNN that vaccinated people likely won’t need a booster shot within a year of receiving their initial doses. Will I need to get a booster shot for Covid? Here are some answers to your booster shot questions...
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: El Salvador Move to Adopt Bitcoin as Legal Tender
item.description: Why El Salvador? On Saturday, El Salvador’s president, Nayib Bukele, said he’s going to send a bill to the legislature to make bitcoin a legal tender in the country. It’d be the first country to formally adopt the cryptocurrency as part of its economy.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: G-7 Ministers Agree to Corporate Minimum Tax
item.description: The Biden administration estimates a global minimum tax system would lead to $500 billion in additional tax revenue for the US over the next decade.  The provision is meant to address European leaders’ concerns that they can’t sufficiently tax tech giants like Facebook and Google, because while those companies make tons of money in Europe, they are based in the US and pay taxes there.   The backstory: Multinational companies have been taking advantage of existing tax rules by shuffling money between jurisdictions with super-low rates.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 7
item.description: Read: Profiles of NBA stars Russell Westbrook and Kevin Durant from the NYT Magazine. On ABC yesterday, Facebook executive Nick Clegg defended the company’s decision to ban former President Trump’s accounts for at least two years.

item.title: Calm App, Sweetgreen, Others Rush to Back Naomi Osaka’s Decision to Leave French Open
item.description: The backstory: Last Sunday, Osaka dropped out of the tournament to focus on her mental health after initially declaring she’d skip mandatory press conferences. Sweetgreen, Nike, Calm, and other brands moved quickly this week to back tennis star Naomi Osaka after she dropped out of this year’s French Open.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 5
item.description: (YouTube) rewatch David Foster Wallace’s commencement speech at Kenyon College in 2005.  Watch: It’s that time of year... “We need more rain, and we need it now."
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Bill Ackman's Proposed SPAC Deal Confuses Just About Everyone
item.description: There’s even more 4D financial chess going on behind the scenes, but the bottom line is that shares in Ackman’s SPAC plummeted yesterday following the announcement, meaning investors doubt Ackman can pull off these business theatrics.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: May Jobs Report Offers Wins, Losses, And Some Hope
item.description: The biggest job gains were in the leisure and hospitality sector, which added 292,000 new jobs, more than the 278,000 jobs the economy added in total in April. The number of workers who claimed unemployment because their employer lost business or closed due to the pandemic dropped by 1.5 million.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Facebook Extends President Trump’s Ban For Two More Years
item.description: Zoom out: Trump’s blog’s failure is a reminder that social platforms like Facebook don’t just offer a place to share snarky opinions, but also an algorithm-amplified megaphone. Facebook had kept a special list of politicians who were allowed to bend its content moderation rules because their opinions were considered “newsworthy content that should, as a general rule, be seen and heard,” Facebook VP of Global Affairs Nick Clegg said in 2019.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Calm App, Sweetgreen, Others Rush to Back Naomi Osaka’s Decision to Leave French Open
item.description: The backstory: Last Sunday, Osaka dropped out of the tournament to focus on her mental health after initially declaring she’d skip mandatory press conferences. Sweetgreen, Nike, Calm, and other brands moved quickly this week to back tennis star Naomi Osaka after she dropped out of this year’s French Open.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: May Jobs Report Offers Wins, Losses, And Some Hope
item.description: The biggest job gains were in the leisure and hospitality sector, which added 292,000 new jobs, more than the total number of jobs the economy added in April (278,000). There are still 7.6 million fewer people employed in the US than before the pandemic.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 5
item.description: (YouTube) rewatch David Foster Wallace’s commencement speech at Kenyon College in 2005.  Watch: It’s that time of year... “We need more rain, and we need it now."

item.title: Bill Ackman's Proposed SPAC Deal Confuses Just About Everyone
item.description: There’s even more 4D financial chess going on behind the scenes, but the bottom line is that shares in Ackman’s SPAC plummeted yesterday following the announcement, meaning investors doubt Ackman can pull off these business theatrics.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Facebook Extends President Trump’s Ban For Two More Years
item.description: Facebook had kept a special list of politicians who were allowed to bend its content moderation rules because their opinions were considered “newsworthy content that should, as a general rule, be seen and heard,” Facebook VP of Global Affairs Nick Clegg said in 2019. The independent blog Trump launched last month failed to reach even a fraction of the combined 57 million followers he still has on Instagram and Facebook.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Icebreakers with… Uma Valeti
item.description: The company raised $161 million in Series B funding, which included investments from SoftBank Group, Bill Gates, Richard Branson, and Tyson Foods. Now for the last five years, I've been eating it again. The other thing to know is when to go fast and when to go slow. Now his company Upside Foods (previously Memphis Meats) is doing just that: growing real meat in a lab. But I made a promise to myself that I will only eat the meat that we produce.  No. I grew up in a meat-eating family, but during medical school, I stopped eating meat because I thought, "I don't like how meat is coming to the table." So that meant in the last five years, building the company up slowly so people would understand what we're trying to do. Absolutely don't look back because it looks scary if you start looking back. You can go fast on a lot of things, but you have to deliberately slow down for some really important moments. What's your favorite meal made out of Upside Foods's cell-grown meat?
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Paul vs. Mayweather: But...Why?
item.description: Logan Paul, the social media star, will fight Floyd Mayweather Jr., considered one of the best boxers ever, in an exhibition match. If you are one of the many people who decide to watch (it'll likely be one of the most-viewed events of the year), you will probably not see a competitive fight. Paul, who only recently got into boxing, is 0–1 in his career. Paul's often been on the wrong side of law and order. My goal is to be the biggest entertainer on the planet. We don't know how much Logan will make from the match, but it's going to be a lot—Mayweather is poised to make $102 million tonight, according to The Sun.Bottom line: In the end, what Mayweather and the Paul brothers are really fighting for is our eyeballs.
item.author: Neal Freyman
